matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) in Markdown Converter URL Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe SSRF vulnerability in the URL converter/markdown converter endpoint. The expected finding describes SSRF allowing bypass of localhost restriction to access admin endpoints. The actual finding confirms this by demonstrating successful exploitation of the url parameter to fetch http://localhost:80/admin/flag endpoint, retrieving the flag without authentication. The vulnerability locations align - both are in the URL conversion functionality that accepts user-supplied URLs.

matched.location: /convert endpoint - url parameter with file:// protocol
matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) with Local File Access
matched.matchReason: This is an extension of the same SSRF vulnerability in the URL converter. The expected finding mentions SSRF in the URL converter endpoint. The actual finding demonstrates the SSRF vulnerability also supports file:// protocol for local file access (/etc/passwd), which is part of the broader SSRF vulnerability affecting the same endpoint and code location.

matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: Sensitive Information Disclosure via Environment Variable Exposure (SSRF)
matched.matchReason: Both findings relate to SSRF in the URL converter endpoint allowing access to restricted resources. The expected finding describes SSRF allowing 'Access to sensitive data (flag)' and 'Internal network enumeration'. The actual finding demonstrates this exact scenario - using SSRF to access /proc/self/environ and exposing environment variables. The vulnerability is the same SSRF in the URL converter allowing arbitrary resource access.

extra.title: Unauthenticated Access to Admin Flag - Critical Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not previously documented in expected findings. This represents a broken access control vulnerability separate from SSRF, where the /admin/flag endpoint is completely accessible without authentication. While this can be exploited via SSRF, it is also independently exploitable through direct HTTP requests.

extra.title: Unauthenticated Admin Panel Access - Flag Endpoint Accessible
extra.assessment: New discovery - Related to the above but documents the entire admin panel being unprotected. This is a distinct broken access control vulnerability where both /admin panel and /admin/flag are accessible without authentication or authorization checks.

extra.title: Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Markdown Conversion
extra.assessment: New discovery - XSS vulnerability through improper HTML sanitization of markdown conversion output. The markdown converter renders HTML/JavaScript injection payloads (script tags, img tags with event handlers, SVG tags) directly without escaping.

extra.title: Reflected XSS via Script Tag in Markdown Text Input
extra.assessment: New discovery - Specific reflected XSS vulnerability where script tags in markdown_text parameter are rendered unescaped in the response, allowing arbitrary JavaScript execution in victim's browser.

extra.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) - Missing CSRF Token Protection
extra.assessment: New discovery - CSRF vulnerability where POST requests to /convert endpoint lack CSRF token validation. The endpoint accepts requests from external origins without challenge, allowing attackers to trick users into performing unwanted actions.

extra.title: Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in /convert Endpoint via data: URL Parameter
extra.location: /convert endpoint - url parameter with data: scheme
extra.assessment: New discovery - Reflected XSS through data: URL scheme in the url parameter. The application processes data: URLs containing HTML/JavaScript without proper escaping, allowing JavaScript execution through specially crafted URLs.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Application is missing critical HTTP security headers (X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Strict-Transport-Security, Content-Security-Policy, Referrer-Policy) that provide browser-level protections against common web vulnerabilities.

extra.title: Stored XSS via Markdown Reference-Style Links with JavaScript Protocol
extra.location: /convert endpoint - markdown_text parameter with reference-style link syntax
extra.assessment: New discovery - Stored XSS through markdown reference-style link definitions. Markdown links with javascript: protocol URLs are not filtered, resulting in clickable links that execute arbitrary JavaScript when clicked.
